summary: 115 (63%) of all 186 patients diagnosed with laboratory-confirmed MERS-CoV infection were available from 115 (63%) of the 1,456 patients in Saudi Arabia as of 4 May 20162,11,12,13,14. we identified published data on exposure periods and onset dates for 34 patients of the 1,456 patients in Saudi Arabia as of 4 May 20162,11,12,13,14. lognormal distribution had the best BIC value with an 1.13 (0.94–1.40) Sex Female — 1.00 Male — 0.89 (0.76–1.04) Location Saudi Arabia 1.00 1.00 South Korea 1.42 (1.18–1.71) 1.40 (1. in a hospital outbreak in the eastern province of Saudi Arabia, one of the 186 cases was reported to have an incubation period of 21 days or longer. this indicates that long incubation periods are possible. this difference could be related to the transmission dynamics of MERS-CoV infection with only secondary cases. a higher infecting dose could have been transmitted by the index case leading to a shorter incubation period compared with cases associated with “indirect” transmission that may have been responsible for transmission in different zones of the emergency room. this difference is an artifact of different approaches to data collection or reporting in south Korea and in Saudi Arabia. the length of incubation period of MERS-CoV infections appeared to vary depending on the location of the outbreak. we retrieved publicly available data from multiple sources, including the Korea Center for Disease Control and Prevention, the Korean Ministry of Health and Welfare, and local Korean news reports. interval-censored data are a special type of survival data. it is possible to “reverse” the time axis considering Sk as the origin and Xk as the outcome time, if the density function for infection is uniform in chronologic time22. the incubation period distribution was estimated using first the interval-censored data and compared between the different parametric models. we used a linear regression model on the log of the incubation period (assuming that incubation periods generally followed lognormal distributions) approach 2: resampling approach We defined another multiple linear regression model using incubation times resampled from the 10,000 posterior samples. the probability P(i) was similarly defined as in equation (3) and for each patient with interval-censored exposure data, we estimated 10,000 posterior samples for the incubation time. the day of symptoms onset was defined as the day when clinical symptoms related to MERS-CoV infection first occurred. non-specific symptoms such as fever, chills, shortness of breath, cough, sputum, sore throat, myalgia, diarrhea, nausea and vomiting. the incubation period Tk for each case k is defined as Tk = Sk–Xk, where Sk is the symptom onset time. non-parametric estimation of a distribution based on interval-censored data can be done with the generalized non-parametric maximum likelihood estimator developed by Turnbull25. the incubation period distribution was estimated using first the interval-censored data and compared between the different parametric models. we used a linear regression model on the log of the incubation period. we estimated = (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, k,,,
